author: jacobkaufmann
content:
Question on the discv5/overlay routing tables that I could not conclusively figure out. If a node is in the overlay routing table, will it necessarily be in the underlying discv5 routing table?

For context, we will need to build and manage a separate routing table for each overlay network a portal node participates in. I'm not sure if there needs to be some sync mechanism so that particular events (e.g. evictions) that occur on the discv5 routing table "bubble up" automatically to the routing table(s) of the overlay network(s)? Otherwise, we may have to "rediscover" those events at the overlay level. However, if a node, or even most nodes, that are in the overlay table are unlikely to be in the discv5 table, then such a mechanism adds complexity without much benefit

author: jason.carver
content: It's totally plausible that a node gets evicted from the underlying while still in the overlay (which is a key reason we track them separately). So, üëç for not worrying about propagating events across tables.

author: pipermerriam
content:
I started this document today.  It's a WIP but the intent was to write down in a very granular manner all of the "units" of functionality that go into a full state network portal client.

https://notes.ethereum.org/8LbisMwtR4yK64SBosb_2g#A---Base-Protocol

This document is not going to be inline with the current spec but my plan is to work on updating the spec alongside this document.  If the implementation teams find this useful, it might be a good way to track relative progress on the individual implementations.

author: pipermerriam
content: My intention is also to add dependency links between different items to form a sort of DAG of the different units of functionality

author: pipermerriam
content: I'm trying to keep it agnostic of specific implementation details, but there is definitely going to be some level of architecture-opinionatedness with respect to how different things are implemented.

author: pipermerriam
content: I literally do this every time I share a new document on hackmd... it's now public
